Using Facebook (and I say Facebook because other services aren't nearly as proliferate in their public information) is a sure way to create awkward situations between family, friends, and business prospects. Even if you carefully tailor your account to privatize your information, by nature of the service, you inevitably will expose something you wish would not be.

I haven't used facebook since it went from college networks only to public. I urge others to do the same, but I understand that almost everyone does and that's not so easy to do.

Ultimately you have to understand you are exposed if you opt in using the service. This should be a clear warning from the getco. If you care at all, delete your account now or never sign up.

If you can't say anything at least inocuous about a person, don't...not even in a memo or a letter or even email.  People save these things and they will sooner or later come back to haunt you.  I wouldn't even say anything damaging about myself or someone else on the phone...

there are definitely things that should be kept offline. ever witness a couple go through a divorce, reflecting their real-life turmoil by way of fb or twitter updates? heart-wrenching, and possibly uncomfortable. the internet is a great way to stay connected, but the information flow is in our own hands. it's always good practice to read everything you type before you click the submit key.

Thank You for reminding me that the US as a society fast on its way to losing its humanitarian bearings. What happened to the ertswhile universally admired beacon of freedom and justice?

Have you ever stopped to consider that those tired masses that descended on US shores were actually looking to escape from corruption and economic dysfunction; that they are overwhelmingly hard working, honest people; that they surmounted enormous odds in order to have a shot at a better life?

Initiative and enterprise - i.e. actually doing something to improve your lot - is what characterizes most immigrants, 'illegal' or not. It is precisely these 'can-do' workers that enrich any society that succeeds in attracting them. One upon a time the US actually rewarded such people and reaped the benefits.

Your and your country's ever-increasing level of xenophobia attests to a society in frank (and sad) decline: "Let's blame it all on those bloody illegals!"

Wake up, sir: your attitude is inhuman, lacks compassion, makes no sense and denotes a disturbing level of knee-jerk simple-mindedness. What is it that you will tell that American serviceman who fought your war in Afghanistan and whose wife fears deportation (see NYT)?

Please have a heart (and a mind) and give me back the one and only country in history that was worth admiring without restraint: The same one you, and people like you are doing your utmost to destroy.

I have been a democrat since I could vote - no, since I could read. One primary reason for my party affiliation is that I have always considered democrats to be the party of fairness, sympathy, and reason; a healthy contrast to often hard-line, chest-thumping republicans. I also thought, until today, that democrats would, when tested, stick more closely to the Constitution.

This move, by a president I supported, goes beyond misguided. It is pure cowardice. The purpose of Miranda warnings was, and is, to give meaning to the Fifth Amendment's command against self-incriminating statements, to prevent coercive interrogations, and to safeguard the right to counsel. Its history has been largely a success: criminals are still convicted, and the police can still do their jobs. They just can't keep you from speaking to a lawyer, or lock you in a cell until you break. Miranda rights are not some liberal plot to set criminals free: they stem from the Constitution, and they should not be so lightly cast aside just because a single incompetent loser tried to wreak havoc in Times Square.

There is already a public safety exception to the rule, which they used in this case. Shahzad talked, and gave out valuable information. If anything, his case is a perfect reason for retaining Miranda rights.

Democrats will not win from this move - they will lose loyalists like me, and gain no respect from independents who will rightfully see this as pandering. Republicans won't gain anything either. And the Constitution will undoubtedly suffer. The only winners are the ignorant radicals in the hills of Pakistan, who now know that their war is inexpensive indeed: a couple tanks of gasoline, an alarm clock, and some commercial-grade fertilizer, and we'll turn on ourselves.
With out the rule of law, Orwell will laugh in his grave.
I like this logic. You Mirandize the guy. He waives his Miranda rights and starts talking and never stops. And Obama uses that as an excuse to cripple Miranda.

This is fascinating. The President is the constitutional law professor, not Bush - yet in one fell swoop (this announcement being that swoop), he has given an imprimatur of approval to all the Bush administration did in the name of fighting terrorism. And to be clear, the Bush administration gave their edicts at a time much closer to 911 - when fear was easier to monger. Add to this that the event prompting Obama's newly proposed policy is a US citizen alleged to engage in terrorism, and it becomes eye-popping. Miranda is given by first contact responders - usually police officers or FBI agents - at a time when the investigation is just beginning, before it can be classified as terrorism. Thus, any person engaged in any criminal act that might cause fear to the general public (the general definition of terrorism) should not receive Miranda warning.

Fascinating indeed.

Miranda warnings themselves do need to be curtailed, back to their 1966 beginnings, but curtailed for all, not a select few.

Holder is basing his view on the famous New York v. Quarles case and the June 12, 1984 5-4 Supreme Court ruling on the Miranda Exception: 'The U.S. Supreme Court held that an officer's immediate concern with protecting the safety and welfare of the public represented a justified exception to the Miranda rule."
An imminent danger to public safety trumps the right of the suspect, United States citizens Faisal Shahzad, not to incriminate himself when police confront him on suspicion of committing a crime. Like Quarles, the suspect could have detonated his Times Sq. bomb or if the police arrested him on suspicion before the bomb detonated , the police could have asked him whether a nearby smoking car was his and was it a bomb about to blow passer byes, the police officer and the suspect to smithereens. If the suspect said yes, and the policeman arrested him, evacuated Times Square, called in the bomb squad to defuse the bomb, and later the court ruled that the officer ought not to have informed the suspect that he need not answer the police officer's questions, there would be calls to overrule Miranda in every arrest: "The most important issue addressed by this case was whether an incriminating statement regarding information about where the respondent hid his gun, could be accepted as testimonial evidence at trial if a police officer failed to provide a Fifth Amendment Miranda rights warning before questioning his suspect. The U.S. Supreme Court reversed judgments of lower courts and explained that an exception to the Miranda rule was justified because the officer believed he needed to ensure public safety. In ruling as acceptable a departure from the required, very precise instructions of the Miranda rule, which ensured a suspect would not be subject to self-incrimination if Miranda warnings were not given, the U.S. Supreme Court gave guidance that in circumstances where public safety was at risk, it may be necessary and correct to forego Miranda warnings.
"On 11 September 1980, shortly after midnight, two police officers, Frank Craft and Sal Scarring, were on patrol when a woman came to their car and told them she had been raped. She provided a description of an black male, six feet tall, armed, and wearing a black jacket. She also told officers he fled into a supermarket. Officer Craft rushed in to apprehend the suspect while his partner called for assistance. He recognized a man who matched the description and gave chase. Craft ordered his suspect to stop and put his hands over his head. Other officers convened and surrounded the suspect in back of the store, but Officer Kraft was the first to reach the man. Handcuffing the suspect, the officer noticed the man's empty shoulder holster and asked him where the gun was. The suspect nodded his head toward some empty boxes answering, 'The gun is over there.' Officer Craft secured the weapon then returned to inform the suspect, Benjamin Quarles, of his Miranda rights. Quarles decided to waive his Miranda rights and answer the officer's questions without an attorney's presence. He stated that he bought the revolver in Miami, Florida, and it was his."
So what was the officer to do? Leave the possibility open that the suspect had a gun either hidden on his person or somewhere he could use it against the officer and the public? If the police had arrested the suspect Faisel
